China+86-991-8580032+86-991-8580032jdz@xju.edu.cn772007122007186Thematic issue: Electron delocalization and aromaticity9099151562007281120061562007772007© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20072007Abstract

Three new manganese complexes, [Mn(PPeAP-INH)(CH3OH)2]n(CHCl3) (1) [PPeAP-INH=N-(1-phenyl-3-phenylethyl-4-ethylene-5-pyrazolone isoniazid, INH = isoniazid], [Mn2(PM4MbP-INH)2(CH3OH)4](CH3OH) (2·CH3OH), [PM4MbP-INH=N-(1-phenyl-3-methyl-4-(p-methylbenzoylene)-5-pyrazolone) isoniazid)] and [Mn2(PPePeP-INH)2(CH3OH)4] (3) [PPePeP-INH=N-(1-phenyl-3-phenylethyl-4-phenylethylene-5-pyrazolone) isoniazid] have been prepared, aiming at the formation of extended coordination polymer with Mn(II) ions. Formation of the corresponding manganese-ligand complexes has been monitored and characterized by chemical and spectroscopic techniques. X-ray diffraction analyses of available single crystals revealed 1D polymeric patterns of supramolecular system. Among them, the dimers of 2 and 3, bridged by two methanol molecules, are extended by hydrogen bond of O–H···N to form the 1D chain. In these three new complexes which are all octahedral coordination environments, the N(5) atom of the pyridine heterocycles plays a very important role in building the bridged polymeric chain.

The syntheses and characterization of N-donor of ligands with pyridine heterocycle linked metal complexes are recently attracting considerable attention for potential building multiplicity [1]. Among them, the isoniazid (INH) which was first utilized in clinical trials in 1951 [2], an inexpensive and relatively safe drug, continues to be one of the most successful antibiotics used to treat tuberculosis [3]. On the other hand, manganese complexes are largely investigated, since they are of importance in several fields, for instances, materials chemistry [4], catalysis [5], or biochemistry [6], as well as their mixed-valence manganese complexes [7] and optically active [8] Mn(III) complexes.

4-acyl pyrazolones are efficient extractants of metal ions, and they have potential to form different types of coordination compounds due to tautomeric effect of enol form and keto form [9]. In addition, they can form a variety of Schiff bases and are reported to be superior reagents in biological, clinical, and analytical applications [10]. In previous studies, we have synthesized a series of 4-acyl pyrazolone derivatives with methyl or phenyl group in position 3 of pyrazole [11] and reported several transition metal complexes [12]. In order to examine further the coordination abilities and complexation behavior of pyrazolone-based ligands and isoniazid, as well as the formation of extended coordination polymer with metal ions, we have extended the study on the syntheses of novel acylpyrazolone derivations and their transition metal complexes. In this article, the syntheses, crystal structures and thermal behavior of three new 1D Mn(II) complexes with N-(1-phenyl-3-phenylethyl-4-ethylene-5-pyrazolone) isoniazid (PPeAP-INH), N-(1-phenyl-3-methyl-4-(p-methylbenzoylene)-5-pyrazolone) isoniazid (PM4MbP-INH) and N-(1-phenyl-3-phenylethyl-4-phenylethylene-5-pyrazolone) isoniazid (PPePeP-INH) are reported.

ExperimentalPhysical measurements and materials

Elemental analyses of carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen were performed on FLASHEA 1112 Series NCHS-O analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on BRUKER EQUINOX-55 spectrophotometer within 400–4000 cm−1 using the samples prepared as pellets with KBr. Thermal analyses were carried out on NETZSCH STA 449  C instrument at a temperature range of 30–700 °C with a heating rate of 20 °C·min−1 in an atmosphere of flowing air. All reagents purchased from commercial sources were used as received. PPeAP, PM4MbP, PPePeP, and INH were prepared according to the literature methods [13–15].

Preparation of ligandsPreparation of PPeAP-INH [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR16">16</xref>]

PPeAP (2.923 g, 10 mmol) was solved in ethanol (20 mL) at 80 °C, to this solution was added INH (1.372 g, 10 mmol) and the mixture was refluxed for 3 h. Upon cooling to room temperature, the red solid was obtained from the mixture. The precipitated product was filtered, dried in air, and purified by recrystallization from ethanol. Yield 66.15%. Anal. Calcd. for C24H21N5O2: C, 70.06; H, 5.14; N, 17.02%; Found: C, 70.42; H, 5.43; N, 16.82%.

Preparation of PM4MbP-INH and PPePeP-INH.

The procedure for the preparation of ligands PM4MbP-INH and PPePeP-INH are similar to that of PPeAP-INH except for the replacement of PPeAP with PM4MbP and PPePeP. For PM4MbP-INH, Yield: 58.74%. Anal. Calcd. for C24H21N5O2: C, 70.06; H, 5.14; N, 17.02%; Found: C, 69.76; H, 5.47; N, 17.12%. For PPePeP-INH, Yield: 67.69%. Anal. Calcd. for C30H25N5O2: C, 73.90; H, 5.17; N, 14.36%; Found: C, 73.59; H, 5.48; N, 14.59%.

Preparation of complexesPreparation of <bold>1</bold>

To a solution of PPeAP-INH (0.2557 g, 0.5 mmol) in methanol (50 mL) was added a solution of Mn(OAc)2·4H2O (0.1226 g, 0.5 mmol) in methanol (5 mL) at 60 °C with continuous stirring for 3 h. The resulted solution was allowed to cool in room temperature, and the dark brown precipitate was collected by suction filtration, washed with 1:1 (v/v) methanol–water and dried in air. The brown single crystals suitable for analysis were obtained by slowly evaporating the mixed solvent solution of CHCl3 and CH3OH at room temperature for a few days. Yield: 60.38%. Anal. Calcd. For C27H28Cl3N5O4Mn: C, 50.06; H, 4.36; N, 10.81%; Found: C, 50.38; H, 4.68; N, 10.53%.

Preparation of complex <bold>2</bold> and <bold>3</bold>

The procedure for the preparation of complex 2 and 3 are similar to that of 1 besides the replacement of PM4MbP-INH and PPePeP-INH with PPeAP-INH. The filtrations were left to stand for over one week under ambient conditions to produce blown crystals for the X-ray structural analysis. For 2, Yield: 78.24%. Anal. Calcd. for C54H62N10O10Mn2: C, 57.86; H, 5.57; N, 12.49%; Found: C, 58.01; H, 5.43; N, 12.23%. For 3, Yield: 65.34%. Anal. Calcd. For C64H62N10O8Mn2: C, 63.57; H, 5.17; N, 11.58%; Found: C, 63.69; H, 5.42; N, 11.32%.

X-ray crystallography

Intensity data for the compounds were collected at 293(2) K on a Bruker SMART-CCD diffractometer for 1 and 153(2) K on Rigaku R-axis Spider diffractometer for 2 and 3 with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data reductions and absorption corrections were performed with the SAINT and SADABS software packages, respectively. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 [17], and were refined by full matrix least-squares methods using SHELXL-97 [18]. Anisotropic displacement parameters were refined for all non-hydrogen atoms. H atoms on oxygen atoms and nitrogen atoms were located from the Fourier maps, and all of the other H atoms were placed in geometrically idealized positions. Crystallographic data and other pertinent information are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table 2. Summary for hydrogen bonds data is given in Table 3.

Results and discussionIR spectra

The most important IR absorption bands of the ligands and complexes are listed in Table 4. The broad peaks in the range 3024–3028 cm−1 correspond to the υ(NH) stretching vibration [19]. The strong bands of 1580 cm−1 and 1680 cm−1 are assigned to υ(C=O) of the pyrazolone-ring and υ(C=O) of the lateral chain, respectively [20]. All these suggest that the structure of the ligand in the solid state is the keto form.

The infrared spectra of complexes exhibit new bands at about 1336–1447 cm−1 due to υ(C–O). Meanwhile, there are new bands between 1568–1592 cm−1 in the complexes, which are assigned to υ(–C=N–N=C–) of hydrazones. From these observations, it is concluded that the ligand reacts in the enol form with prototropy, which incorporates into two proton transfers. Then the ligands lose the enolic protons and coordinates to the central metal atoms in the complexes. The weak bands in the region 465–545 cm−1 are due to M–N and M–O stretching vibrations. In the complex 1 containing pyridine nitrogen coordinated to Mn(II), a shift toward high frequency of υ(C=N) is known to occur. It is believed that the nitrogen of the pyridine heterocycle is coordinated to Mn(II). The results also confirmed by the crystal structure analyses below.

Crystal structures

A single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that in the octahedral complex 1, each Mn(II) is coordinated by two PPeAP-INH ligands and two methanol molecules, while one of the PPeAP-INH ligand acts as a bridge linking the neighboring Mn(II) ions to form infinite 1D chain (Fig. 1). The octahedral coordination around Mn1 ion is composed of O1, O2, N3 and from PPeAP-INH, N5A from another PPeAP-INH (symmetry code: −x + 1/2, y−1/2, −z + 1/2) and O3, O4 from methanol molecules. The equatorial plane of the octahedron is defined by O1, O2, O3, and N3 with the average bias of the least squares is 0.0033 Å. The bond distances of Mn1–O1/2/3 and Mn1–N3 are 1.924(4) Å, 1.911(4) Å, 1.859(4) Å, 1.999(5) Å, respectively. The drifting distance between the Mn atom and the equatorial plane is 0.0317 Å, indicating that it is slightly apart equatorial plane. In addition, the axes of the octahedron are held by O4 and N5A atoms. The elongated bond lengths Mn1–O4 and Mn1–N5A are 2.235(4) Å and 2.374(5) Å, respectively, which show that the coordination geometry around Mn(II) ion reflects Jahn–Teller effect. The values of trans bond angles also indicate that the coordination is distorted octahedral, with O(4)–Mn(1)–N(5)A, O(2)–Mn(1)–O(1) and O(3)–Mn(1)–N(3) angles of 175.31(2)°, 172.35(2)° and 175.31(2)°, respectively.

The Fig. 1 reveals that 1 is a 1D zigzag polymeric chain, there are Mn(II) of [Mn(PPeAP-INH)(CH3OH)2] adopting a bridging structure (Mn–N(5)), which results in the structure forming a 1D zigzag chain.

The centrosymmetric unit 2 (Fig. 2a) contains a dimer in which two distorted octahedral Mn(II) centers are bridged equatorially by two oxygen atoms of methanol molecule at the distance of 3.131(4) Å. The O1, N3, O2, and O4 atoms constitute the equatorial plane in which the small bite angle of the O2–Mn–N3 = (80.01(5)°) gives the main distortion on the octahedral geometry, while the axial positions are filled by the O3 and O4A atoms from the terminal methanol molecule and μ-methanol molecule, respectively. The bond distances of Mn–O1/4/2 and Mn–N3 are 1.915(1) Å, 1.889(1) Å, 1.920(1) Å, 1.996(1) Å, respectively, and obviously, the axial bond of Mn–O3, Mn1–O4A with bond distances of 2.262(1) Å and 2.211(1) Å are longer than that in the equatorial plane. Therefore, the coordination geometry around the manganese ion in 2 is similar to 1. Bond angles also show that the coordination geometries are distorted octahedron, with O(1)–Mn–O(2), O(4)–Mn–N(3) and O(4)A–Mn–O(3) angles of 171.76(4)°, 171.02(5)° and 174.93(4)°, respectively.

Hydrogen bonds of 2 make the binuclear entity extend toward an infinite 1D supramolecular chain (Fig. 2b). Unlike 1, the acylhydrazine nitrogen atom that is not covalently coordinating to Mn(II) center, but forms hydrogen bonds with the next unit by O···N hydrogen bonds [O(3)–H3(O)···N5A] and links the repeating units of 2 to form an 1D supramolecular chain along c direction. Meanwhile one of the oxygen atom in the PM4MbP-INH and one oxygen atom of crystalline methanol molecule formed intermolecular hydrogen bonds [O(5)–H(5O)···O(2)a] (a: −x + 2, −y,−z + 1), which may be the main reason for making the 1D supramolecular chain stable.

In the structure of 3 (Fig. 3a), two octahedrally coordinated Mn(II) ions are bridged by two oxygen atoms of methanol molecules. The atoms O1, N3, O2, and O3 are composed of the equatorial plane of the octahedron and the axis of the octahedron are held by O3A and O4. The drifting distance between the Mn1 and plane is 0.0061 Å. The binuclear units are linked into a 1D chain along c direction (Fig. 3b) via O–H···N intermolecular hydrogen bond ([O(4)–H(4O)···N(5)a] (a: −x + 1, −y + 2, −z)).

In the 1D zigzag polymeric coordination chain of 1, the N(5) atoms are very important in building the infinite chain (Fig. 1). In the packing arrangement of 2 and 3, the hydrogen bonds [O–H···N(5)] form an 1D supramolecular chain held by hydrogen bonding interactions of [O(3)–H3(O)···N5A] for 2 and [O(4)–H(4O)···N(5)A] for 3. The steric effects of the different 4-acyl substituents of ligands are the main reason for the different bonding fashion between center Mn(II) atoms and N(5) atoms of the pyridine heterocycles. In the position 4 of pyrazole, the substituents are ethylene, p-methylbenzoylene, and phenylethylene for 1, 2, and 3 respectively. The volumes of the p-methylbenzoylene and phenylethylene are almost the same and that of ethylene is much smaller than them. So the steric effect between Mn(II) and N(5) of 1 is smaller than these of 2, 3. As a result, N(5) atom bridges the other Mn(II) center to form a 1D polymer chain in 1, while in 2, 3, they form the same hydrogen bonds linked 1D supramolecular chain.

Thermal properties

In order to investigate the stability of three complexes, thermogravimetric analyses (TG) on the crystalline samples were carried out under an air atmosphere with a heating rate of 20 °C min−1.

There are two separate weight loss steps for 1. The complex stable until 220 °C and the decomposition of the complex finishes at 480 °C in two overlapping endothermic steps. These stages correspond to decomposition of CHCl3 molecule and two coordinated methanol molecules in the temperature range of 230–300 °C and the PPeAP-INH in the temperature range of 300–480 °C. The release of the isoniazid is an endothermic process and resembles the thermal decomposition of isoniazid complexes reported by previous investigators [21]. The final residue, maybe estimated, as manganese sesquioxide or manganese tetraoxide, has the observed mass 15.98% [22].

The TG curve of 2 is divided into three stages. The first weight loss in the temperature range 60–140 °C corresponds to the loss of crystalline methanol molecule. The hydrogen-bonded 1D supramolecular chain is not stable in the temperature range of 120–200 °C. The second and third weight loss is 80.83% in the temperature range of 210–430 °C corresponding to the removal of the coordinated methanol molecules and ligands. The sample does not lose weight at the temperatures higher than 440 °C. The final residue has the observed mass 14.08%.

The decomposition of 3 undergoes in two stages. Degradation of two coordination methanol molecules takes place in the first stage between 120 and 190 °C with a mass loss of 5.61% (Calc.: 5.30%). The second is 73.75% in the temperature range of 260–430 °C corresponding to the removal of the coordinated methanol molecules and ligands. The sample dose not loses weight at the temperatures higher than 430 °C. The final residue has the observed mass 14.50%.

From the above results it is possible to suggest the stability of 1 is higher than that of 2 and 3; 3 is more stable than 2. For the former, it maybe attribute to the different construction of unit, as 1 is bridged polymeric chain, 2 and 3 are hydrogen linked supramolecular chain. For the latter, the crystalline methanol molecule in 2 gives the main reason of less stable than 3.

Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully prepared three new complexes resulting from 4-acyl pyrazolones organic ligands and Mn(OAc)2·4H2O. The complex 1 exhibits an infinite zigzag polymeric chain and the complex 2, 3 are hydrogen bonded 1D supramolecular chain. Due to the steric effect from the position 4 of pyrazole heterocycle, the N(5) atoms of the nicotinic heterocycles play very important role in building the 1D polymeric chain for 1 and the hydrogen bond (O–H···N) linked 1D supramolecular chain for 2 and 3. The results of thermal analyses are important for understanding the relationship between crystal structures and their thermo-stability. The higher-exothermic temperature under the linear heating rate indicates that 1 is good heating stability complex, which is consistent with the stable character of the structure.

Supplementary material

Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic data Center, 12 Union Road, Cambridge, Cb2 1EZ, UK (fax: +44-1223-336033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk) and are available on request quoting the deposition numbers CCDC-615097, CCDC-615096 and CCDC-625994 for 1, 2, and 3, respectively. TG-DTA plots for 1–3 are available from the authors on request.

X-ray diffraction analyses of available single crystals revealed 1D polymeric patterns of supramolecular system. Among them, the dimers of 2 and 3, bridged by two methanol molecules, are extended by hydrogen bond of O-H⋅⋅⋅N to form the 1D chain. In these three new complexes which are all octahedral coordination environments, the N(5) atom of the pyridine heterocycles plays a very important role in building the bridged polymeric chain.KeywordsMn(II) complexPyrazoloneIsoniazidCrystal structuresThermal analysisvolume-issue-count6issue-article-count37issue-toc-levels0issue-copyright-holderSpringer Science+Business Media, LLCissue-copyright-year2007article-contains-esmNoarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2007article-registration-date-month6article-registration-date-day15article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/11224_2007_Article_9213.pdftarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2008issue-online-date-month1issue-online-date-day3issue-print-date-year2008issue-print-date-month1issue-print-date-day3issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryTheoretical and Computational Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryComputer Applications in Chemistry open-accessfalseIntroductionThe syntheses and characterization of N-donor of ligands with pyridine heterocycle linked metal complexes are recently attracting considerable attention for potential building multiplicity [1]. Among them, the isoniazid (INH) which was first utilized in clinical trials in 1951 [2], an inexpensive and relatively safe drug, continues to be one of the most successful antibiotics used to treat tuberculosis [3]. On the other hand, manganese complexes are largely investigated, since they are of importance in several fields, for instances, materials chemistry [4], catalysis [5], or biochemistry [6], as well as their mixed-valence manganese complexes [7] and optically active [8] Mn(III) complexes.4-acyl pyrazolones are efficient extractants of metal ions, and they have potential to form different types of coordination compounds due to tautomeric effect of enol form and keto form [9]. In addition, they can form a variety of Schiff bases and are reported to be superior reagents in biological, clinical, and analytical applications [10]. In previous studies, we have synthesized a series of 4-acyl pyrazolone derivatives with methyl or phenyl group in position 3 of pyrazole [11] and reported several transition metal complexes [12]. In order to examine further the coordination abilities and complexation behavior of pyrazolone-based ligands and isoniazid, as well as the formation of extended coordination polymer with metal ions, we have extended the study on the syntheses of novel acylpyrazolone derivations and their transition metal complexes. In this article, the syntheses, crystal structures and thermal behavior of three new 1D Mn(II) complexes with N-(1-phenyl-3-phenylethyl-4-ethylene-5-pyrazolone) isoniazid (PPeAP-INH), N-(1-phenyl-3-methyl-4-(p-methylbenzoylene)-5-pyrazolone) isoniazid (PM4MbP-INH) and N-(1-phenyl-3-phenylethyl-4-phenylethylene-5-pyrazolone) isoniazid (PPePeP-INH) are reported.ExperimentalPhysical measurements and materialsElemental analyses of carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen were performed on FLASHEA 1112 Series NCHS-O analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on BRUKER EQUINOX-55 spectrophotometer within 400-4000 cm-1 using the samples prepared as pellets with KBr. Thermal analyses were carried out on NETZSCH STA 449  C instrument at a temperature range of 30-700 °C with a heating rate of 20 °C⋅min-1 in an atmosphere of flowing air. All reagents purchased from commercial sources were used as received. PPeAP, PM4MbP, PPePeP, and INH were prepared according to the literature methods [13-15].Preparation of ligandsPreparation of PPeAP-INH [16]PPeAP (2.923 g, 10 mmol) was solved in ethanol (20 mL) at 80 °C, to this solution was added INH (1.372 g, 10 mmol) and the mixture was refluxed for 3 h. Upon cooling to room temperature, the red solid was obtained from the mixture. The precipitated product was filtered, dried in air, and purified by recrystallization from ethanol. Yield 66.15%. Anal. Calcd. for C24H21N5O2: C, 70.06; H, 5.14; N, 17.02%; Found: C, 70.42; H, 5.43; N, 16.82%.Preparation of PM4MbP-INH and PPePeP-INH.The procedure for the preparation of ligands PM4MbP-INH and PPePeP-INH are similar to that of PPeAP-INH except for the replacement of PPeAP with PM4MbP and PPePeP. For PM4MbP-INH, Yield: 58.74%. Anal. Calcd. for C24H21N5O2: C, 70.06; H, 5.14; N, 17.02%; Found: C, 69.76; H, 5.47; N, 17.12%. For PPePeP-INH, Yield: 67.69%. Anal. Calcd. for C30H25N5O2: C, 73.90; H, 5.17; N, 14.36%; Found: C, 73.59; H, 5.48; N, 14.59%.Preparation of complexesPreparation of 1To a solution of PPeAP-INH (0.2557 g, 0.5 mmol) in methanol (50 mL) was added a solution of Mn(OAc)2⋅4H2O (0.1226 g, 0.5 mmol) in methanol (5 mL) at 60 °C with continuous stirring for 3 h. The resulted solution was allowed to cool in room temperature, and the dark brown precipitate was collected by suction filtration, washed with 1:1 (v/v) methanol-water and dried in air. The brown single crystals suitable for analysis were obtained by slowly evaporating the mixed solvent solution of CHCl3 and CH3OH at room temperature for a few days. Yield: 60.38%. Anal. Calcd. For C27H28Cl3N5O4Mn: C, 50.06; H, 4.36; N, 10.81%; Found: C, 50.38; H, 4.68; N, 10.53%.Preparation of complex 2 and 3The procedure for the preparation of complex 2 and 3 are similar to that of 1 besides the replacement of PM4MbP-INH and PPePeP-INH with PPeAP-INH. The filtrations were left to stand for over one week under ambient conditions to produce blown crystals for the X-ray structural analysis. For 2, Yield: 78.24%. Anal. Calcd. for C54H62N10O10Mn2: C, 57.86; H, 5.57; N, 12.49%; Found: C, 58.01; H, 5.43; N, 12.23%. For 3, Yield: 65.34%. Anal. Calcd. For C64H62N10O8Mn2: C, 63.57; H, 5.17; N, 11.58%; Found: C, 63.69; H, 5.42; N, 11.32%.X-ray crystallographyIntensity data for the compounds were collected at 293(2) K on a Bruker SMART-CCD diffractometer for 1 and 153(2) K on Rigaku R-axis Spider diffractometer for 2 and 3 with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data reductions and absorption corrections were performed with the SAINT and SADABS software packages, respectively. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 [17], and were refined by full matrix least-squares methods using SHELXL-97 [18]. Anisotropic displacement parameters were refined for all non-hydrogen atoms. H atoms on oxygen atoms and nitrogen atoms were located from the Fourier maps, and all of the other H atoms were placed in geometrically idealized positions. Crystallographic data and other pertinent information are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table 2. Summary for hydrogen bonds data is given in Table 3. Results and discussionIR spectraThe most important IR absorption bands of the ligands and complexes are listed in Table 4. The broad peaks in the range 3024-3028 cm-1 correspond to the υ(NH) stretching vibration [19]. The strong bands of 1580 cm-1 and 1680 cm-1 are assigned to υ(C=O) of the pyrazolone-ring and υ(C=O) of the lateral chain, respectively [20]. All these suggest that the structure of the ligand in the solid state is the keto form. The infrared spectra of complexes exhibit new bands at about 1336-1447 cm-1 due to υ(C-O). Meanwhile, there are new bands between 1568-1592 cm-1 in the complexes, which are assigned to υ(-C=N-N=C-) of hydrazones. From these observations, it is concluded that the ligand reacts in the enol form with prototropy, which incorporates into two proton transfers. Then the ligands lose the enolic protons and coordinates to the central metal atoms in the complexes. The weak bands in the region 465-545 cm-1 are due to M-N and M-O stretching vibrations. In the complex 1 containing pyridine nitrogen coordinated to Mn(II), a shift toward high frequency of υ(C=N) is known to occur. It is believed that the nitrogen of the pyridine heterocycle is coordinated to Mn(II). The results also confirmed by the crystal structure analyses below.Crystal structuresA single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that in the octahedral complex 1, each Mn(II) is coordinated by two PPeAP-INH ligands and two methanol molecules, while one of the PPeAP-INH ligand acts as a bridge linking the neighboring Mn(II) ions to form infinite 1D chain (Fig. 1). The octahedral coordination around Mn1 ion is composed of O1, O2, N3 and from PPeAP-INH, N5A from another PPeAP-INH (symmetry code: -x + 1/2, y-1/2, -z + 1/2) and O3, O4 from methanol molecules. The equatorial plane of the octahedron is defined by O1, O2, O3, and N3 with the average bias of the least squares is 0.0033 Å. The bond distances of Mn1-O1/2/3 and Mn1-N3 are 1.924(4) Å, 1.911(4) Å, 1.859(4) Å, 1.999(5) Å, respectively. The drifting distance between the Mn atom and the equatorial plane is 0.0317 Å, indicating that it is slightly apart equatorial plane. In addition, the axes of the octahedron are held by O4 and N5A atoms. The elongated bond lengths Mn1-O4 and Mn1-N5A are 2.235(4) Å and 2.374(5) Å, respectively, which show that the coordination geometry around Mn(II) ion reflects Jahn-Teller effect. The values of trans bond angles also indicate that the coordination is distorted octahedral, with O(4)-Mn(1)-N(5)A, O(2)-Mn(1)-O(1) and O(3)-Mn(1)-N(3) angles of 175.31(2)°, 172.35(2)° and 175.31(2)°, respectively. The Fig. 1 reveals that 1 is a 1D zigzag polymeric chain, there are Mn(II) of [Mn(PPeAP-INH)(CH3OH)2] adopting a bridging structure (Mn-N(5)), which results in the structure forming a 1D zigzag chain.The centrosymmetric unit 2 (Fig. 2a) contains a dimer in which two distorted octahedral Mn(II) centers are bridged equatorially by two oxygen atoms of methanol molecule at the distance of 3.131(4) Å. The O1, N3, O2, and O4 atoms constitute the equatorial plane in which the small bite angle of the O2-Mn-N3 = (80.01(5)°) gives the main distortion on the octahedral geometry, while the axial positions are filled by the O3 and O4A atoms from the terminal methanol molecule and μ-methanol molecule, respectively. The bond distances of Mn-O1/4/2 and Mn-N3 are 1.915(1) Å, 1.889(1) Å, 1.920(1) Å, 1.996(1) Å, respectively, and obviously, the axial bond of Mn-O3, Mn1-O4A with bond distances of 2.262(1) Å and 2.211(1) Å are longer than that in the equatorial plane. Therefore, the coordination geometry around the manganese ion in 2 is similar to 1. Bond angles also show that the coordination geometries are distorted octahedron, with O(1)-Mn-O(2), O(4)-Mn-N(3) and O(4)A-Mn-O(3) angles of 171.76(4)°, 171.02(5)° and 174.93(4)°, respectively. Hydrogen bonds of 2 make the binuclear entity extend toward an infinite 1D supramolecular chain (Fig. 2b). Unlike 1, the acylhydrazine nitrogen atom that is not covalently coordinating to Mn(II) center, but forms hydrogen bonds with the next unit by O⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds [O(3)-H3(O)⋅⋅⋅N5A] and links the repeating units of 2 to form an 1D supramolecular chain along c direction. Meanwhile one of the oxygen atom in the PM4MbP-INH and one oxygen atom of crystalline methanol molecule formed intermolecular hydrogen bonds [O(5)-H(5O)⋅⋅⋅O(2)a] (a: -x + 2, -y,-z + 1), which may be the main reason for making the 1D supramolecular chain stable.In the structure of 3 (Fig. 3a), two octahedrally coordinated Mn(II) ions are bridged by two oxygen atoms of methanol molecules. The atoms O1, N3, O2, and O3 are composed of the equatorial plane of the octahedron and the axis of the octahedron are held by O3A and O4. The drifting distance between the Mn1 and plane is 0.0061 Å. The binuclear units are linked into a 1D chain along c direction (Fig. 3b) via O-H⋅⋅⋅N intermolecular hydrogen bond ([O(4)-H(4O)⋅⋅⋅N(5)a] (a: -x + 1, -y + 2, -z)). In the 1D zigzag polymeric coordination chain of 1, the N(5) atoms are very important in building the infinite chain (Fig. 1). In the packing arrangement of 2 and 3, the hydrogen bonds [O-H⋅⋅⋅N(5)] form an 1D supramolecular chain held by hydrogen bonding interactions of [O(3)-H3(O)⋅⋅⋅N5A] for 2 and [O(4)-H(4O)⋅⋅⋅N(5)A] for 3. The steric effects of the different 4-acyl substituents of ligands are the main reason for the different bonding fashion between center Mn(II) atoms and N(5) atoms of the pyridine heterocycles. In the position 4 of pyrazole, the substituents are ethylene, p-methylbenzoylene, and phenylethylene for 1, 2, and 3 respectively. The volumes of the p-methylbenzoylene and phenylethylene are almost the same and that of ethylene is much smaller than them. So the steric effect between Mn(II) and N(5) of 1 is smaller than these of 2, 3. As a result, N(5) atom bridges the other Mn(II) center to form a 1D polymer chain in 1, while in 2, 3, they form the same hydrogen bonds linked 1D supramolecular chain.Thermal propertiesIn order to investigate the stability of three complexes, thermogravimetric analyses (TG) on the crystalline samples were carried out under an air atmosphere with a heating rate of 20 °C min-1.There are two separate weight loss steps for 1. The complex stable until 220 °C and the decomposition of the complex finishes at 480 °C in two overlapping endothermic steps. These stages correspond to decomposition of CHCl3 molecule and two coordinated methanol molecules in the temperature range of 230-300 °C and the PPeAP-INH in the temperature range of 300-480 °C. The release of the isoniazid is an endothermic process and resembles the thermal decomposition of isoniazid complexes reported by previous investigators [21]. The final residue, maybe estimated, as manganese sesquioxide or manganese tetraoxide, has the observed mass 15.98% [22].The TG curve of 2 is divided into three stages. The first weight loss in the temperature range 60-140 °C corresponds to the loss of crystalline methanol molecule. The hydrogen-bonded 1D supramolecular chain is not stable in the temperature range of 120-200 °C. The second and third weight loss is 80.83% in the temperature range of 210-430 °C corresponding to the removal of the coordinated methanol molecules and ligands. The sample does not lose weight at the temperatures higher than 440 °C. The final residue has the observed mass 14.08%.The decomposition of 3 undergoes in two stages. Degradation of two coordination methanol molecules takes place in the first stage between 120 and 190 °C with a mass loss of 5.61% (Calc.: 5.30%). The second is 73.75% in the temperature range of 260-430 °C corresponding to the removal of the coordinated methanol molecules and ligands. The sample dose not loses weight at the temperatures higher than 430 °C. The final residue has the observed mass 14.50%.From the above results it is possible to suggest the stability of 1 is higher than that of 2 and 3; 3 is more stable than 2. For the former, it maybe attribute to the different construction of unit, as 1 is bridged polymeric chain, 2 and 3 are hydrogen linked supramolecular chain. For the latter, the crystalline methanol molecule in 2 gives the main reason of less stable than 3.ConclusionIn summary, we have successfully prepared three new complexes resulting from 4-acyl pyrazolones organic ligands and Mn(OAc)2⋅4H2O. The complex 1 exhibits an infinite zigzag polymeric chain and the complex 2, 3 are hydrogen bonded 1D supramolecular chain. Due to the steric effect from the position 4 of pyrazole heterocycle, the N(5) atoms of the nicotinic heterocycles play very important role in building the 1D polymeric chain for 1 and the hydrogen bond (O-H⋅⋅⋅N) linked 1D supramolecular chain for 2 and 3. The results of thermal analyses are important for understanding the relationship between crystal structures and their thermo-stability. The higher-exothermic temperature under the linear heating rate indicates that 1 is good heating stability complex, which is consistent with the stable character of the structure.Supplementary materialCrystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic data Center, 12 Union Road, Cambridge, Cb2 1EZ, UK (fax: +44-1223-336033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk) and are available on request quoting the deposition numbers CCDC-615097, CCDC-615096 and CCDC-625994 for 1, 2, and 3, respectively. TG-DTA plots for 1-3 are available from the authors on request.AcknowledgmentThis work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 20366005 and 20462007), the Scientific Research Foundation in Xinjiang Educational Institutions (XJEDU2005S01) and the Young Scholar Science Foundation of Xinjiang University (QN040107).References1.(a) Lu J, Babb AM (2001) Inorg Chem 40:3261; elements.content: Three new manganese complexes, [Mn(PPeAP-INH)(CH3OH)2]n(CHCl3) (1) [PPeAP-INH=N-(1-phenyl-3-phenylethyl-4-ethylene-5-pyrazolone isoniazid, INH = isoniazid], [Mn2(PM4MbP-INH)2(CH3OH)4](CH3OH) (2·CH3OH), [PM4MbP-INH=N-(1-phenyl-3-methyl-4-(p-methylbenzoylene)-5-pyrazolone) isoniazid)] and [Mn2(PPePeP-INH)2(CH3OH)4] (3) [PPePeP-INH=N-(1-phenyl-3-phenylethyl-4-phenylethylene-5-pyrazolone) isoniazid] have been prepared, aiming at the formation of extended coordination polymer with Mn(II) ions. Formation of the corresponding manganese-ligand complexes has been monitored and characterized by chemical and spectroscopic techniques. X-ray diffraction analyses of available single crystals revealed 1D polymeric patterns of supramolecular system. Among them, the dimers of 2 and 3, bridged by two methanol molecules, are extended by hydrogen bond of O–H···N to form the 1D chain. In these three new complexes which are all octahedral coordination environments, the N(5) atom of the pyridine heterocycles plays a very important role in building the bridged polymeric chain.

Abstract

Three new manganese complexes, [Mn(PPeAP-INH)(CH3OH)2]n(CHCl3) (1) [PPeAP-INH=N-(1-phenyl-3-phenylethyl-4-ethylene-5-pyrazolone isoniazid, INH = isoniazid], [Mn2(PM4MbP-INH)2(CH3OH)4](CH3OH) (2⋅CH3OH), [PM4MbP-INH=N-(1-phenyl-3-methyl-4-(p-methylbenzoylene)-5-pyrazolone) isoniazid)] and [Mn2(PPePeP-INH)2(CH3OH)4] (3) [PPePeP-INH=N-(1-phenyl-3-phenylethyl-4-phenylethylene-5-pyrazolone) isoniazid] have been prepared, aiming at the formation of extended coordination polymer with Mn(II) ions. Formation of the corresponding manganese-ligand complexes has been monitored and characterized by chemical and spectroscopic techniques. X-ray diffraction analyses of available single crystals revealed 1D polymeric patterns of supramolecular system. Among them, the dimers of 2 and 3, bridged by two methanol molecules, are extended by hydrogen bond of O-H⋅⋅⋅N to form the 1D chain. In these three new complexes which are all octahedral coordination environments, the N(5) atom of the pyridine heterocycles plays a very important role in building the bridged polymeric chain.

In addition, they can form a variety of Schiff bases and are reported to be superior reagents in biological, clinical, and analytical applications [10]. elements.clean_text: 4-acyl pyrazolones are efficient extractants of metal ions, and they have potential to form different types of coordination compounds due to tautomeric effect of enol form and keto form [9]. In addition, they can form a variety of Schiff bases and are reported to be superior reagents in biological, clinical, and analytical applications [10]. In previous studies, we have synthesized a series of 4-acyl pyrazolone derivatives with methyl or phenyl group in position 3 of pyrazole [11] and reported several transition metal complexes [12]. In order to examine further the coordination abilities and complexation behavior of pyrazolone-based ligands and isoniazid, as well as the formation of extended coordination polymer with metal ions, we have extended the study on the syntheses of novel acylpyrazolone derivations and their transition metal complexes. In this article, the syntheses, crystal structures and thermal behavior of three new 1D Mn(II) complexes with N-(1-phenyl-3-phenylethyl-4-ethylene-5-pyrazolone) isoniazid (PPeAP-INH), N-(1-phenyl-3-methyl-4-(p-methylbenzoylene)-5-pyrazolone) isoniazid (PM4MbP-INH) and N-(1-phenyl-3-phenylethyl-4-phenylethylene-5-pyrazolone) isoniazid (PPePeP-INH) are reported.

elements.content: Elemental analyses of carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen were performed on FLASHEA 1112 Series NCHS-O analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on BRUKER EQUINOX-55 spectrophotometer within 400–4000 cm−1 using the samples prepared as pellets with KBr. Thermal analyses were carried out on NETZSCH STA 449  C instrument at a temperature range of 30–700 °C with a heating rate of 20 °C·min−1 in an atmosphere of flowing air. All reagents purchased from commercial sources were used as received. PPeAP, PM4MbP, PPePeP, and INH were prepared according to the literature methods [13–15].
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Physical measurements and materials

Elemental analyses of carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen were performed on FLASHEA 1112 Series NCHS-O analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on BRUKER EQUINOX-55 spectrophotometer within 400-4000 cm-1 using the samples prepared as pellets with KBr. Thermal analyses were carried out on NETZSCH STA 449  C instrument at a temperature range of 30-700 °C with a heating rate of 20 °C⋅min-1 in an atmosphere of flowing air. All reagents purchased from commercial sources were used as received. PPeAP, PM4MbP, PPePeP, and INH were prepared according to the literature methods [13-15].

elements.content: PPeAP (2.923 g, 10 mmol) was solved in ethanol (20 mL) at 80 °C, to this solution was added INH (1.372 g, 10 mmol) and the mixture was refluxed for 3 h. Upon cooling to room temperature, the red solid was obtained from the mixture. The precipitated product was filtered, dried in air, and purified by recrystallization from ethanol. Yield 66.15%. Anal. Calcd. for C24H21N5O2: C, 70.06; H, 5.14; N, 17.02%; Found: C, 70.42; H, 5.43; N, 16.82%.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of ligands

Preparation of PPeAP-INH [16]

PPeAP (2.923 g, 10 mmol) was solved in ethanol (20 mL) at 80 °C, to this solution was added INH (1.372 g, 10 mmol) and the mixture was refluxed for 3 h. Upon cooling to room temperature, the red solid was obtained from the mixture. The precipitated product was filtered, dried in air, and purified by recrystallization from ethanol. Yield 66.15%. Anal. Calcd. for C24H21N5O2: C, 70.06; H, 5.14; N, 17.02%; Found: C, 70.42; H, 5.43; N, 16.82%.

elements.content: The procedure for the preparation of ligands PM4MbP-INH and PPePeP-INH are similar to that of PPeAP-INH except for the replacement of PPeAP with PM4MbP and PPePeP. For PM4MbP-INH, Yield: 58.74%. Anal. Calcd. for C24H21N5O2: C, 70.06; H, 5.14; N, 17.02%; Found: C, 69.76; H, 5.47; N, 17.12%. For PPePeP-INH, Yield: 67.69%. Anal. Calcd. for C30H25N5O2: C, 73.90; H, 5.17; N, 14.36%; Found: C, 73.59; H, 5.48; N, 14.59%.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of PM4MbP-INH and PPePeP-INH.

The procedure for the preparation of ligands PM4MbP-INH and PPePeP-INH are similar to that of PPeAP-INH except for the replacement of PPeAP with PM4MbP and PPePeP. For PM4MbP-INH, Yield: 58.74%. Anal. Calcd. for C24H21N5O2: C, 70.06; H, 5.14; N, 17.02%; Found: C, 69.76; H, 5.47; N, 17.12%. For PPePeP-INH, Yield: 67.69%. Anal. Calcd. for C30H25N5O2: C, 73.90; H, 5.17; N, 14.36%; Found: C, 73.59; H, 5.48; N, 14.59%.

elements.content: To a solution of PPeAP-INH (0.2557 g, 0.5 mmol) in methanol (50 mL) was added a solution of Mn(OAc)2·4H2O (0.1226 g, 0.5 mmol) in methanol (5 mL) at 60 °C with continuous stirring for 3 h. The resulted solution was allowed to cool in room temperature, and the dark brown precipitate was collected by suction filtration, washed with 1:1 (v/v) methanol–water and dried in air. The brown single crystals suitable for analysis were obtained by slowly evaporating the mixed solvent solution of CHCl3 and CH3OH at room temperature for a few days. Yield: 60.38%. Anal. Calcd. For C27H28Cl3N5O4Mn: C, 50.06; H, 4.36; N, 10.81%; Found: C, 50.38; H, 4.68; N, 10.53%.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of complexes

Preparation of 1

To a solution of PPeAP-INH (0.2557 g, 0.5 mmol) in methanol (50 mL) was added a solution of Mn(OAc)2⋅4H2O (0.1226 g, 0.5 mmol) in methanol (5 mL) at 60 °C with continuous stirring for 3 h. The resulted solution was allowed to cool in room temperature, and the dark brown precipitate was collected by suction filtration, washed with 1:1 (v/v) methanol-water and dried in air. The brown single crystals suitable for analysis were obtained by slowly evaporating the mixed solvent solution of CHCl3 and CH3OH at room temperature for a few days. Yield: 60.38%. Anal. Calcd. For C27H28Cl3N5O4Mn: C, 50.06; H, 4.36; N, 10.81%; Found: C, 50.38; H, 4.68; N, 10.53%.

elements.content: The procedure for the preparation of complex 2 and 3 are similar to that of 1 besides the replacement of PM4MbP-INH and PPePeP-INH with PPeAP-INH. The filtrations were left to stand for over one week under ambient conditions to produce blown crystals for the X-ray structural analysis. For 2, Yield: 78.24%. Anal. Calcd. for C54H62N10O10Mn2: C, 57.86; H, 5.57; N, 12.49%; Found: C, 58.01; H, 5.43; N, 12.23%. For 3, Yield: 65.34%. Anal. Calcd. For C64H62N10O8Mn2: C, 63.57; H, 5.17; N, 11.58%; Found: C, 63.69; H, 5.42; N, 11.32%.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of complex 2 and 3

The procedure for the preparation of complex 2 and 3 are similar to that of 1 besides the replacement of PM4MbP-INH and PPePeP-INH with PPeAP-INH. The filtrations were left to stand for over one week under ambient conditions to produce blown crystals for the X-ray structural analysis. For 2, Yield: 78.24%. Anal. Calcd. for C54H62N10O10Mn2: C, 57.86; H, 5.57; N, 12.49%; Found: C, 58.01; H, 5.43; N, 12.23%. For 3, Yield: 65.34%. Anal. Calcd. For C64H62N10O8Mn2: C, 63.57; H, 5.17; N, 11.58%; Found: C, 63.69; H, 5.42; N, 11.32%.

elements.content: Intensity data for the compounds were collected at 293(2) K on a Bruker SMART-CCD diffractometer for 1 and 153(2) K on Rigaku R-axis Spider diffractometer for 2 and 3 with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data reductions and absorption corrections were performed with the SAINT and SADABS software packages, respectively. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 [17], and were refined by full matrix least-squares methods using SHELXL-97 [18]. Anisotropic displacement parameters were refined for all non-hydrogen atoms. H atoms on oxygen atoms and nitrogen atoms were located from the Fourier maps, and all of the other H atoms were placed in geometrically idealized positions. Crystallographic data and other pertinent information are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table 2. Summary for hydrogen bonds data is given in Table 3.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Intensity data for the compounds were collected at 293(2) K on a Bruker SMART-CCD diffractometer for 1 and 153(2) K on Rigaku R-axis Spider diffractometer for 2 and 3 with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data reductions and absorption corrections were performed with the SAINT and SADABS software packages, respectively. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 [17], and were refined by full matrix least-squares methods using SHELXL-97 [18]. Anisotropic displacement parameters were refined for all non-hydrogen atoms. H atoms on oxygen atoms and nitrogen atoms were located from the Fourier maps, and all of the other H atoms were placed in geometrically idealized positions. Crystallographic data and other pertinent information are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table 2. Summary for hydrogen bonds data is given in Table 3.

The most important IR absorption bands of the ligands and complexes are listed in Table 4. The broad peaks in the range 3024–3028 cm−1 correspond to the υ(NH) stretching vibration [19]. The strong bands of 1580 cm−1 and 1680 cm−1 are assigned to υ(C=O) of the pyrazolone-ring and υ(C=O) of the lateral chain, respectively [20]. All these suggest that the structure of the ligand in the solid state is the keto form.
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

IR spectra

The most important IR absorption bands of the ligands and complexes are listed in Table 4. The broad peaks in the range 3024-3028 cm-1 correspond to the υ(NH) stretching vibration [19]. The strong bands of 1580 cm-1 and 1680 cm-1 are assigned to υ(C=O) of the pyrazolone-ring and υ(C=O) of the lateral chain, respectively [20]. All these suggest that the structure of the ligand in the solid state is the keto form.

bνC=N of the pyridine heterocycle

The infrared spectra of complexes exhibit new bands at about 1336–1447 cm−1 due to υ(C–O). Meanwhile, there are new bands between 1568–1592 cm−1 in the complexes, which are assigned to υ(–C=N–N=C–) of hydrazones. From these observations, it is concluded that the ligand reacts in the enol form with prototropy, which incorporates into two proton transfers. Then the ligands lose the enolic protons and coordinates to the central metal atoms in the complexes. The weak bands in the region 465–545 cm−1 are due to M–N and M–O stretching vibrations. In the complex 1 containing pyridine nitrogen coordinated to Mn(II), a shift toward high frequency of υ(C=N) is known to occur. It is believed that the nitrogen of the pyridine heterocycle is coordinated to Mn(II). The results also confirmed by the crystal structure analyses below.

From these observations, it is concluded that the ligand reacts in the enol form with prototropy, which incorporates into two proton transfers. elements.content: A single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that in the octahedral complex 1, each Mn(II) is coordinated by two PPeAP-INH ligands and two methanol molecules, while one of the PPeAP-INH ligand acts as a bridge linking the neighboring Mn(II) ions to form infinite 1D chain (Fig. 1). The octahedral coordination around Mn1 ion is composed of O1, O2, N3 and from PPeAP-INH, N5A from another PPeAP-INH (symmetry code: −x + 1/2, y−1/2, −z + 1/2) and O3, O4 from methanol molecules. The equatorial plane of the octahedron is defined by O1, O2, O3, and N3 with the average bias of the least squares is 0.0033 Å. The bond distances of Mn1–O1/2/3 and Mn1–N3 are 1.924(4) Å, 1.911(4) Å, 1.859(4) Å, 1.999(5) Å, respectively. The drifting distance between the Mn atom and the equatorial plane is 0.0317 Å, indicating that it is slightly apart equatorial plane. In addition, the axes of the octahedron are held by O4 and N5A atoms. The elongated bond lengths Mn1–O4 and Mn1–N5A are 2.235(4) Å and 2.374(5) Å, respectively, which show that the coordination geometry around Mn(II) ion reflects Jahn–Teller effect. The values of trans bond angles also indicate that the coordination is distorted octahedral, with O(4)–Mn(1)–N(5)A, O(2)–Mn(1)–O(1) and O(3)–Mn(1)–N(3) angles of 175.31(2)°, 172.35(2)° and 175.31(2)°, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structures

A single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that in the octahedral complex 1, each Mn(II) is coordinated by two PPeAP-INH ligands and two methanol molecules, while one of the PPeAP-INH ligand acts as a bridge linking the neighboring Mn(II) ions to form infinite 1D chain (Fig. 1). The octahedral coordination around Mn1 ion is composed of O1, O2, N3 and from PPeAP-INH, N5A from another PPeAP-INH (symmetry code: -x + 1/2, y-1/2, -z + 1/2) and O3, O4 from methanol molecules. The equatorial plane of the octahedron is defined by O1, O2, O3, and N3 with the average bias of the least squares is 0.0033 Å. The bond distances of Mn1-O1/2/3 and Mn1-N3 are 1.924(4) Å, 1.911(4) Å, 1.859(4) Å, 1.999(5) Å, respectively. The drifting distance between the Mn atom and the equatorial plane is 0.0317 Å, indicating that it is slightly apart equatorial plane. In addition, the axes of the octahedron are held by O4 and N5A atoms. The elongated bond lengths Mn1-O4 and Mn1-N5A are 2.235(4) Å and 2.374(5) Å, respectively, which show that the coordination geometry around Mn(II) ion reflects Jahn-Teller effect. The values of trans bond angles also indicate that the coordination is distorted octahedral, with O(4)-Mn(1)-N(5)A, O(2)-Mn(1)-O(1) and O(3)-Mn(1)-N(3) angles of 175.31(2)°, 172.35(2)° and 175.31(2)°, respectively.

elements.content: The Fig. 1 reveals that 1 is a 1D zigzag polymeric chain, there are Mn(II) of [Mn(PPeAP-INH)(CH3OH)2] adopting a bridging structure (Mn–N(5)), which results in the structure forming a 1D zigzag chain.
elements.clean_text: The Fig. 1 reveals that 1 is a 1D zigzag polymeric chain, there are Mn(II) of [Mn(PPeAP-INH)(CH3OH)2] adopting a bridging structure (Mn-N(5)), which results in the structure forming a 1D zigzag chain.

elements.content: The centrosymmetric unit 2 (Fig. 2a) contains a dimer in which two distorted octahedral Mn(II) centers are bridged equatorially by two oxygen atoms of methanol molecule at the distance of 3.131(4) Å. The O1, N3, O2, and O4 atoms constitute the equatorial plane in which the small bite angle of the O2–Mn–N3 = (80.01(5)°) gives the main distortion on the octahedral geometry, while the axial positions are filled by the O3 and O4A atoms from the terminal methanol molecule and μ-methanol molecule, respectively. The bond distances of Mn–O1/4/2 and Mn–N3 are 1.915(1) Å, 1.889(1) Å, 1.920(1) Å, 1.996(1) Å, respectively, and obviously, the axial bond of Mn–O3, Mn1–O4A with bond distances of 2.262(1) Å and 2.211(1) Å are longer than that in the equatorial plane. Therefore, the coordination geometry around the manganese ion in 2 is similar to 1. Bond angles also show that the coordination geometries are distorted octahedron, with O(1)–Mn–O(2), O(4)–Mn–N(3) and O(4)A–Mn–O(3) angles of 171.76(4)°, 171.02(5)° and 174.93(4)°, respectively.

elements.content: Hydrogen bonds of 2 make the binuclear entity extend toward an infinite 1D supramolecular chain (Fig. 2b). Unlike 1, the acylhydrazine nitrogen atom that is not covalently coordinating to Mn(II) center, but forms hydrogen bonds with the next unit by O···N hydrogen bonds [O(3)–H3(O)···N5A] and links the repeating units of 2 to form an 1D supramolecular chain along c direction. Meanwhile one of the oxygen atom in the PM4MbP-INH and one oxygen atom of crystalline methanol molecule formed intermolecular hydrogen bonds [O(5)–H(5O)···O(2)a] (a: −x + 2, −y,−z + 1), which may be the main reason for making the 1D supramolecular chain stable.

Unlike 1, the acylhydrazine nitrogen atom that is not covalently coordinating to Mn(II) center, but forms hydrogen bonds with the next unit by O⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds [O(3)-H3(O)⋅⋅⋅N5A] and links the repeating units of 2 to form an 1D supramolecular chain along c direction. Meanwhile one of the oxygen atom in the PM4MbP-INH and one oxygen atom of crystalline methanol molecule formed intermolecular hydrogen bonds [O(5)-H(5O)⋅⋅⋅O(2)a] (a: -x + 2, -y,-z + 1), which may be the main reason for making the 1D supramolecular chain stable.

elements.content: In the structure of 3 (Fig. 3a), two octahedrally coordinated Mn(II) ions are bridged by two oxygen atoms of methanol molecules. The atoms O1, N3, O2, and O3 are composed of the equatorial plane of the octahedron and the axis of the octahedron are held by O3A and O4. The drifting distance between the Mn1 and plane is 0.0061 Å. The binuclear units are linked into a 1D chain along c direction (Fig. 3b) via O–H···N intermolecular hydrogen bond ([O(4)–H(4O)···N(5)a] (a: −x + 1, −y + 2, −z)).

elements.content: In the 1D zigzag polymeric coordination chain of 1, the N(5) atoms are very important in building the infinite chain (Fig. 1). In the packing arrangement of 2 and 3, the hydrogen bonds [O–H···N(5)] form an 1D supramolecular chain held by hydrogen bonding interactions of [O(3)–H3(O)···N5A] for 2 and [O(4)–H(4O)···N(5)A] for 3. The steric effects of the different 4-acyl substituents of ligands are the main reason for the different bonding fashion between center Mn(II) atoms and N(5) atoms of the pyridine heterocycles. In the position 4 of pyrazole, the substituents are ethylene, p-methylbenzoylene, and phenylethylene for 1, 2, and 3 respectively. The volumes of the p-methylbenzoylene and phenylethylene are almost the same and that of ethylene is much smaller than them. So the steric effect between Mn(II) and N(5) of 1 is smaller than these of 2, 3. As a result, N(5) atom bridges the other Mn(II) center to form a 1D polymer chain in 1, while in 2, 3, they form the same hydrogen bonds linked 1D supramolecular chain.

elements.content:
In order to investigate the stability of three complexes, thermogravimetric analyses (TG) on the crystalline samples were carried out under an air atmosphere with a heating rate of 20 °C min−1.

There are two separate weight loss steps for 1. The complex stable until 220 °C and the decomposition of the complex finishes at 480 °C in two overlapping endothermic steps. These stages correspond to decomposition of CHCl3 molecule and two coordinated methanol molecules in the temperature range of 230–300 °C and the PPeAP-INH in the temperature range of 300–480 °C. The release of the isoniazid is an endothermic process and resembles the thermal decomposition of isoniazid complexes reported by previous investigators [21]. The final residue, maybe estimated, as manganese sesquioxide or manganese tetraoxide, has the observed mass 15.98% [22].

Thermal properties

In order to investigate the stability of three complexes, thermogravimetric analyses (TG) on the crystalline samples were carried out under an air atmosphere with a heating rate of 20 °C min-1.

There are two separate weight loss steps for 1. The complex stable until 220 °C and the decomposition of the complex finishes at 480 °C in two overlapping endothermic steps. These stages correspond to decomposition of CHCl3 molecule and two coordinated methanol molecules in the temperature range of 230-300 °C and the PPeAP-INH in the temperature range of 300-480 °C. The release of the isoniazid is an endothermic process and resembles the thermal decomposition of isoniazid complexes reported by previous investigators [21]. The final residue, maybe estimated, as manganese sesquioxide or manganese tetraoxide, has the observed mass 15.98% [22].

elements.content: The TG curve of 2 is divided into three stages. The first weight loss in the temperature range 60–140 °C corresponds to the loss of crystalline methanol molecule. The hydrogen-bonded 1D supramolecular chain is not stable in the temperature range of 120–200 °C. The second and third weight loss is 80.83% in the temperature range of 210–430 °C corresponding to the removal of the coordinated methanol molecules and ligands. The sample does not lose weight at the temperatures higher than 440 °C. The final residue has the observed mass 14.08%.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully prepared three new complexes resulting from 4-acyl pyrazolones organic ligands and Mn(OAc)2·4H2O. The complex 1 exhibits an infinite zigzag polymeric chain and the complex 2, 3 are hydrogen bonded 1D supramolecular chain. Due to the steric effect from the position 4 of pyrazole heterocycle, the N(5) atoms of the nicotinic heterocycles play very important role in building the 1D polymeric chain for 1 and the hydrogen bond (O–H···N) linked 1D supramolecular chain for 2 and 3. The results of thermal analyses are important for understanding the relationship between crystal structures and their thermo-stability. The higher-exothermic temperature under the linear heating rate indicates that 1 is good heating stability complex, which is consistent with the stable character of the structure.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully prepared three new complexes resulting from 4-acyl pyrazolones organic ligands and Mn(OAc)2⋅4H2O. The complex 1 exhibits an infinite zigzag polymeric chain and the complex 2, 3 are hydrogen bonded 1D supramolecular chain. Due to the steric effect from the position 4 of pyrazole heterocycle, the N(5) atoms of the nicotinic heterocycles play very important role in building the 1D polymeric chain for 1 and the hydrogen bond (O-H⋅⋅⋅N) linked 1D supramolecular chain for 2 and 3. The results of thermal analyses are important for understanding the relationship between crystal structures and their thermo-stability. The higher-exothermic temperature under the linear heating rate indicates that 1 is good heating stability complex, which is consistent with the stable character of the structure.

PPeAP (2.923 g, 10 mmol) was solved in ethanol (20 mL) at 80 °C, to this solution was added INH (1.372 g, 10 mmol) and the mixture was refluxed for 3 h. Upon cooling to room temperature, the red solid was obtained from the mixture. The precipitated product was filtered, dried in air, and purified by recrystallization from ethanol. Yield 66.15%. Anal. Calcd. for C24H21N5O2: C, 70.06; H, 5.14; N, 17.02%; Found: C, 70.42; H, 5.43; N, 16.82%.

Preparation of PM4MbP-INH and PPePeP-INH.

The procedure for the preparation of ligands PM4MbP-INH and PPePeP-INH are similar to that of PPeAP-INH except for the replacement of PPeAP with PM4MbP and PPePeP. For PM4MbP-INH, Yield: 58.74%. Anal. Calcd. for C24H21N5O2: C, 70.06; H, 5.14; N, 17.02%; Found: C, 69.76; H, 5.47; N, 17.12%. For PPePeP-INH, Yield: 67.69%. Anal. Calcd. for C30H25N5O2: C, 73.90; H, 5.17; N, 14.36%; Found: C, 73.59; H, 5.48; N, 14.59%.

Preparation of complexesPreparation of <bold>1</bold>

To a solution of PPeAP-INH (0.2557 g, 0.5 mmol) in methanol (50 mL) was added a solution of Mn(OAc)2·4H2O (0.1226 g, 0.5 mmol) in methanol (5 mL) at 60 °C with continuous stirring for 3 h. The resulted solution was allowed to cool in room temperature, and the dark brown precipitate was collected by suction filtration, washed with 1:1 (v/v) methanol–water and dried in air. The brown single crystals suitable for analysis were obtained by slowly evaporating the mixed solvent solution of CHCl3 and CH3OH at room temperature for a few days. Yield: 60.38%. Anal. Calcd. For C27H28Cl3N5O4Mn: C, 50.06; H, 4.36; N, 10.81%; Found: C, 50.38; H, 4.68; N, 10.53%.

Preparation of complex <bold>2</bold> and <bold>3</bold>

The procedure for the preparation of complex 2 and 3 are similar to that of 1 besides the replacement of PM4MbP-INH and PPePeP-INH with PPeAP-INH. The filtrations were left to stand for over one week under ambient conditions to produce blown crystals for the X-ray structural analysis. For 2, Yield: 78.24%. Anal. Calcd. for C54H62N10O10Mn2: C, 57.86; H, 5.57; N, 12.49%; Found: C, 58.01; H, 5.43; N, 12.23%. For 3, Yield: 65.34%. Anal. Calcd. For C64H62N10O8Mn2: C, 63.57; H, 5.17; N, 11.58%; Found: C, 63.69; H, 5.42; N, 11.32%.

In order to investigate the stability of three complexes, thermogravimetric analyses (TG) on the crystalline samples were carried out under an air atmosphere with a heating rate of 20 °C min−1.

There are two separate weight loss steps for 1. The complex stable until 220 °C and the decomposition of the complex finishes at 480 °C in two overlapping endothermic steps. These stages correspond to decomposition of CHCl3 molecule and two coordinated methanol molecules in the temperature range of 230–300 °C and the PPeAP-INH in the temperature range of 300–480 °C. The release of the isoniazid is an endothermic process and resembles the thermal decomposition of isoniazid complexes reported by previous investigators [21]. The final residue, maybe estimated, as manganese sesquioxide or manganese tetraoxide, has the observed mass 15.98% [22].

The TG curve of 2 is divided into three stages. The first weight loss in the temperature range 60–140 °C corresponds to the loss of crystalline methanol molecule. The hydrogen-bonded 1D supramolecular chain is not stable in the temperature range of 120–200 °C. The second and third weight loss is 80.83% in the temperature range of 210–430 °C corresponding to the removal of the coordinated methanol molecules and ligands. The sample does not lose weight at the temperatures higher than 440 °C. The final residue has the observed mass 14.08%.

The decomposition of 3 undergoes in two stages. Degradation of two coordination methanol molecules takes place in the first stage between 120 and 190 °C with a mass loss of 5.61% (Calc.: 5.30%). The second is 73.75% in the temperature range of 260–430 °C corresponding to the removal of the coordinated methanol molecules and ligands. The sample dose not loses weight at the temperatures higher than 430 °C. The final residue has the observed mass 14.50%.
